subject: Re: [junit] How to count test assertions
msgSnippet: So said  SteveKelem   on  2003-01-09 ... Then fix the test generator. I use an explicit failure to indicate that I have not yet written
messageBody:
So said SteveKelem <s_kelem@...> on 2003-01-09
--------------------

>JUnit (3.8.1) counts the number of test methods that pass/fail.
>With some of the test generation methods, such as JUnitDoclet, empty
>methods are generated (a good thing) for each class. But when the
>tests are run, the generated document shows that all these methods
>pass (questionably good). This gives a false sense that the code
>being tested is being tested, when it really isn't because the test
>bodies are empty.

Then fix the test generator. I use an explicit failure to indicate that
I have not yet written the test. In fact, in my "JUnit: A Starter
Guide", I suggest starting with this test:

testSomething:
fail("Not yet implemented")

As I add code to the test, I keep the fail statement in there until I
have decided that the test is complete.

It sounds to me like you should consider changing the test generator,
and not JUnit, to solve your problem.

>Is there a way to track the number of assertions that pass/fail
>instead of the number of methods that are invoked in the test classes?

Yes, there is a way. An event/listener mechanism on the assert* methods
would do the job. It's not difficult to write.

<snip />
>This way more the classes for which tests haven't yet been written,
>but the skeleton is up and running, would show up in the report as 0
>tests run, rather than whatever number of test skeletons have been
>generated
>and may or may not be empty.

Again, I strongly suggest that you generate tests that fail, or even
generate a warning, rather than rely on the test/assertion count. How
will you know that MyTestCase has 0 assertions when you run it in a big
test suite?

Good luck.
